intro: Schumannia karelinii, commonly known as the Karelin's grass of heaven, is a rare and striking plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Caucasus. It is a member of the Asparagaceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and dense clusters of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces striking purple or pinkish inflorescences that bloom in late summer, adding a dramatic visual element to its habitat. Schumannia karelinii thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in rocky or alpine areas. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
